title: Tools used for picking up rice sacks
content:
accession_no_csv: 2016-00583

  Image: 

  object_work_type: hand tools

  title_text: Tools used for picking up rice sacks

  preference: main

  title_language: 

  creation_date: 1950s-1970s

  creation_place_original_location: Singapore

  inscriptions: 

  inscription_language: 

  shape: L-shaped

  materials_name: plastic (organic material) metal

  techniques_name: forming (physical activity) metalworking

  object_colour: multicoloured

  physical_appearance: A set of four hand tools are displayed in the image. Two of them are long while the other two are short. The long pair of hand tools contains a wooden L-shaped handle
 while the short pair contains a wooden curved handle. On one of the short pair of hand tools
 there is a hfinger-sized hole in its handle. All four hand tools have a metal shaft that curves inwards to form hooks.

  subject_terms_1: implements (object genre) hooks (object genres) tools

  subject_terms_2: Hooks Tools

  sgcool_label_text: These tools belonged to Mr Neo Kim Teah
 who had worked as a coolie in Singapore from the 1950s to the 1970s. Part of his job was to unload sackfuls of rice from boats docked at the Singapore River
 and to transport them to the godowns. Such tools were essential during this process. Mr Neo had arrived in Singapore as a young child in the late 1930s and he had stayed in the Sungei Kadut area.

metadata.title_text: Tools used for picking up rice sacks
metadata.physical_appearance: A set of four hand tools are displayed in the image. Two of them are long while the other two are short. The long pair of hand tools contains a wooden L-shaped handle, while the short pair contains a wooden curved handle. On one of the short pair of hand tools, there is a hfinger-sized hole in its handle. All four hand tools have a metal shaft that curves inwards to form hooks.
metadata.sgcool_label_text: These tools belonged to Mr Neo Kim Teah, who had worked as a coolie in Singapore from the 1950s to the 1970s. Part of his job was to unload sackfuls of rice from boats docked at the Singapore River, and to transport them to the godowns. Such tools were essential during this process. Mr Neo had arrived in Singapore as a young child in the late 1930s and he had stayed in the Sungei Kadut area.
